dialogues.text: Good Morning
Good morning. You're early as usual.
Yes, I like checking to ensure everything I need for the day is ready.

text: Hey, Adwoa. Throughout your day, you are going to need some things to do your job well. Let's learn how to use them.

Adwoa, the Storage Cupboard contains 11 items you may need during your patient visits today.

Click the CUPBOARD ICON to activate the Storage Cupboard
To use an item from your Storage Cupboard & Troley, click on it. Let's test this. Click the 'Hello Nurse' item.
Well done, Adwoa. Now click the flashing Hello Nurse icon to dismiss it.
Now, Click the HANDWASHING ICON to activate the Handwashing Toolkit

Adwoa, as you know, infection prevention is of utmost importance, therefore we have provided you with the following: Sanitizer, Soap and Water. Choose the right method as and when needed. It works just as selecting an item in your cupboard.
Now, get ready for your day by washing your hands. Click the Soap/Water Icon.
Well done, Adwoa. Now click the flashing icon to dismiss it.
Finally, Click the MATRON ICON to see any tips your matron might have for you as you treat patients.

Adwoa, getting help from senior colleagues and supervisors helps you adhere to best practices and keep your patients safe and healthy.

Matron Evelyn, is here to help remind you of the important things, as you work. Now, get a pep talk from Matron Evelyn and let's start the day.

Click the Matron Icon.

dialogues.text: Hi Adwoa. Remember to be polite to your patients, stick to the guidelines and get help if you are unsure.
All the Best! See you soon.

text: Well done, Adwoa. You're ready for your patients.

dialogues.text: Madam, your hospital card.
Here it is.
Let me find the folder.
Here you are.
Thank You.

text: Mother and child arrive at Nurses desk at OPD.

dialogues.text: Good Morning
Good Morning
What brings you here this morning?
Madam, what's your child's name
Yaw Manu.
He's sick?
Aunty Nurse. He's vomiting every food and drink and is very hot.
He's also not active at all. Has no interest in anything.
Is that so?
It might be Malaria? Let me make sure...

info_start: You suspect this child might have severe malaria based on three (3) symptoms: Vomiting all food and drink, very hot for several days, apathetic. Now you need to confirm it, what will you do?
1. Additional symptoms for confirming severe malaria in a child are listed below, mixed with other irrelevant symptoms.
2. Pick the correct symptoms from the list below, by clicking on all of them.
3. When you are done, click the CONFIRM button.

text: Severe malaria is life threatening and failing to diagnose this can lead to very bad results for your patients.  Knowing the symptoms to use to differentiate severe from uncomplicated malaria is therefore essential.

dialogues.text: This child has a stiff neck, yellow eyes and palmar pallor. It can only mean one thing.

text:
Oh No! You misread the symptoms and came up with a wrong diagnosis.
Symptoms for Uncomplicated Malaria DOES NOT include: Stiff Neck; Palmar pallor and Yellow eyes.
As a result, the child's condition will worsen and the child will go into convulsive fits. The next 48hours will be critical and there is no guarantee, the child will survive.

Let's REWIND and make sure this child stays alive.

TRY AGAIN!

dialogues.text: Madam. Your child has a severe case of malaria we must act quickly!

text:
You've just diagnosed conclusively that this child has severe malaria. It's time to keep a calm head and act decisively to try to save this child from any further complications.

We've broken the next actions you can take down into four steps.

Hey, Adwoa, what is the first step you must take after diagnosing this child with Severe Malaria?

 Go into your Cupboard and Trolley
 Select the first Item you need to perform the first action, you need to take.
To use an item from your Storage Cupboard & Trolley, click on it.

Sigh. We don't know why you're stuck but let's help you out. A child with a fever needs to be cooled down, first and foremost. What you need is to give the child a sponge bath.  Let's spell it out for you, use a T-O-W-E-L.

dialogues.text: Madam. I am sponging your child with lukewarm water to reduce the fever.

text: Good Job Nurse! Let's continue to manage the case. Select the next item you need, for the next action.

Sigh. You were on the right path but you're lost now. Sponging seeks to cool a child down. To check if this is working or not, what must you do? Check the child's temperature! This way you can check if the fever is reducing effectively.  You can thank us later, your patient awaits!

Sigh. You were on the right path but you're lost now. Sponging seeks to cool a child down. To check if this is working or not, what must you do? Check the child's temperature! This way you can check if the fever is reducing effectively.  You can thank us later, your patient awaits!

Click the MATRON ICON to see any tips your matron might have for you as you treat patients.

dialogues.text: Adwoa! After sponging, you need to check the child's temperature to observe the current state of the fever.
All the Best! See you soon.

text: Great! This child is closer and closer to getting better.  Select the next item you need.

You are 2/3 on fighting the fever but missed an important part. Stabilizing the fever. An anti-pyretic ensures the child's temperature stabilizes until further treatment I administered. Now you know, go act on it.

You are 2/3 on fighting the fever but missed an important part. Stabilizing the fever. An anti-pyretic ensures the child's temperature stabilizes until further treatment I administered. Now you know, go act on it.

You are 2/3 on fighting the fever but missed an important part. Stabilizing the fever. An anti-pyretic ensures the child's temperature stabilizes until further treatment I administered. Now you know, go act on it.

dialogues.text: This should help keep his body temperature down.

text: One more step! Almost ready to hand over to the next level in managing this case. What's the next item and action?

You fought the fever the right way,  but forgot that documenting cases is as vital as any other part of the healthcare process. Without properly documented history, treatment can be haphazard or interventions duplicated, which is dangerous for patients.

You fought the fever the right way,  but forgot that documenting cases is as vital as any other part of the healthcare process. Without properly documented history, treatment can be haphazard or interventions duplicated, which is dangerous for patients.

dialogues.text: This child's fever is now under control. What's next?

text: You must learn to triage your patients properly. A child with severe malaria must go straight to the consult room after you control their fever and document the case. Waiting in a queue can jeopardize the life of the child. Just ensure you explain to those in the queue it is an emergency.

dialogues.text: Madam. I will begin treating your child immediately.
The medicine will help him get better soon, rather than later.

text: Never assume you know better than tried and tested processes and procedures. Protocols are established to ensure the optimum healthcare for patients in all aspects of their treatment. Each part of the treatment cycle (nurse, lab technician, doctor, administrator) exists for a reason. This is unacceptable!

dialogues.text: Madam since your child has Severe Malaria, we need to see the doctor immediately.
Aunty Nurse, the people will be angry.
I will explain to them, it's an emergency.
Yes. Come in.
Dr. Asiama. Please this child has severe malaria.
Becky, take over immediately. We need a microscopy test first.
Let's see the child's age and weight, so we use the right dosage of Quinine
Yes Doctor.
We also need to monitor urine output and glucose levels after giving Quinine.
It's good this child got here in time.

text: Hey Adwoa, are you not forgetting something? We need to document this case, just as with every other case for proper case management.

narration.text: Kojo arrives at OPD of Clinic where nurse is seated.

pages.text: A new patient. What should I do?

dialogues.text: Good Morning. You're welcome.
Good Morning. Thank You.
What brings you here this morning?
Adwoa. It is respectful to always ask for the name of your patients and address them politely and respectfully.
This deepens the trust between you and your patients during your consultation
Yes. What's wrong with you?
I have a fever which started about 3 days, I'm feeling cold, and shivering, I have a headache and just feel sick.
Is that so.
It might be malaria. Let me make sure.
Do you feel anything else?
Bitter taste in my mouth, body pains and I have been sweating more than usual.

text: You are still confusing uncomplicated and severe malaria and even worse, failing to differentiate between those and other illnesses with fever as a symptom such as Typhoid or an ear infection. Time to wake up!

You are still confusing uncomplicated and severe malaria and even worse, failing to differentiate between those and other illnesses with fever as a symptom such as Typhoid or an ear infection. Time to wake up!

You are still confusing uncomplicated and severe malaria and even worse, failing to differentiate between those and other illnesses with fever as a symptom such as Typhoid or an ear infection. Time to wake up!

dialogues.text: Kojo I'm sure its uncomplicated malaria from your symptoms
Aunty nurse, I'm not surprised. I have military mosquitoes paa at my workshop.
Ha ha ha. Now we know, so we have to take the next step.

pages.text: What's the next step in Kojo's treatment?

text: Final diagnosis without any evidence from some form of investigation or laboratory findings is outside the guidelines for malaria treatment. Always confirm your suspicions with an RDT test or full microscopy lab for MPs to ensure you are treating the patient correctly. Also the protocol for most hospitals would require you to document and refer to doctor.

dialogues.text: I will give you a 3 day treatment course of Artesunate Amodiaquine
Okay, Nurse. Anything you say I will do.
Hi Adwoa, I can see you administering malaria treatment. I didnt see you use an RDT?
No doctor. The symptoms were clear so I didn't want to waste an RDT cassette.
Waste? The reason they are here is to be used. Never make assumptions. Always test.
Kojo, I need to do a Rapid Diagnostic Test to be sure. Is that okay?
Yes. Anything you say I will do.

info_start: You suspect your patient Kojo has uncomplicated malaria and following guidelines, you want to confirm with an RDT test. Ready?
1. We've used 9 steps to describe the correct sequence of actions for diagnosing severe malaria.
2. The list on the left is all jumbled up.
3. Arrange them in the correct sequence on the right.

text: You failed to select the correct sequence of actions for diagnosing severe malaria

dialogues.text: Okay, the sample is ready. Results should be ready in 15 minutes.
15 minutes gone. Tests are ready.

pages.text: What do the test results say?

dialogues.text: Positive. Kojo, you definitely have malaria.
What do we do, Aunty Nurse?

text: No! The results you saw on the RDT Cassette were NOT inconclusive.

Rapid Test Kits exist to make the lives of health professionals easier and those of patients safer with fast, rapid diagnosis. You were able to perform the tests correctly, but if you can't interpret the results, then all the value is lost.

dialogues.text: Inconclusive. Kojo, something went wrong with the test.
Really? What do we do, Aunty Nurse?

text: Rapid Test Kits exist to make the lives of health professionals easier and those of patients safer with fast, rapid diagnosis. You were able to perform the tests correctly, but if you can't interpret the results, then all the value is lost.

dialogues.text: Negative. Kojo, you do not have malaria.
Really? Then what can it be?

info_start: You've done at RDT test for Kojo based on an initial diagnosis of Uncomplicated Malaria. The test indicates Kojo is positive for Malaria. How will you manage Kojo?
1. Below is a list of five (5) possible actions you can take to manage Kojo's case.
2. Select the correct actions from the list on your left and place it in the slot on your right.

text: Proper case management after a correct diagnosis is just as important as the diagnosis itself. Getting any of this wrong can lead to serious consequences for your patients. It's time to get it right, once and for all.

dialogues.text: Kojo, please make sure you follow the dosage exactly as I said. It's also on the box
Yes, Aunty Nurse. I will.
Good bye and if anything feels wrong, come back and consult me.

text: Adwoa. Record Kojo's case into his hospital folder.

narration.text: 2 WEEKS LATER Adwoa at OPD. Kojo comes back

dialogues.text: Kojo. I treated you two weeks ago for malaria. What brings you back?
Aunty Nurse. I took all the medicine but I am feeling sick still.
I'm feeling cold, and shivering, I have a headache and still have a fever
The soldier mosquitoes at my workshop are hard to defeat.
What is it?

text: Your patients have absolute faith in you. They have no idea you are actually just doing guess work and you are not sure what you are doing. Typhoid may have similar symptoms to malaria but following guidelines would help you make proper diagnosis.

dialogues.text: Kojo, I think you may have Typhoid.
I'll treat you and you will be fine.
Thank you. What would I do if you weren't so good at your
Kojo, I suspect the treatment may have failed.
Failed? I did everything you said.
Let's figure it out together.

text: Taking shortcuts and making assumptions are an easy and lazy form of health care. Not following proper guidelines for diagnosis and case management puts the lives of your patients at risk.

dialogues.text: Kojo. I told you to use Insecticide Treated Nets and to be more careful.
I am sure, you have malaria again. Spray your workshop.
Aunty Nurse. I swear, this time, I will kill them all.
I will treat you for malaria again.
Thank you. What would I do if you weren't so good at your job

text:
You suspect Treatment Failure in one of your patients. You need to confirm or refute this suspicion. Work with your patient to figure it out.

1. The following are possible questions, you can ask your patient to confirm or refute Treatment Failure.
2. Choose YES or NO for the questions you should ask.
3. Got It? Let's do this!

Ironic. You failed at treatment failure. It's important to ensure you identify treatment failure versus the person getting re-infected. This enables the health system to identify what may be causing failures and rectify them.

dialogues.text: Kojo, you followed all my instructions well.
However, it is still possible you may have been infected again. Let's do an RDT test to confirm
Okay.

text: Adwoa. Let's use the Malaria RDT to test for malaria.

dialogues.text: We have to wait for some time
Yes, I remember, 15 minutes.
Kojo, the test is positive. We already established that your previous malaria treatment was adequate.
You took the full dosage and did not vomit. This is treatment failure for sure.
The soldier mosquitoes were too much for the medicine?
Kojo. It's not soldier mosquitoes. However, we must make sure you get the best treatment now.

info_start: Adwoa, one of your patients at your Primary Care Facility, is suffering from Treatment Failure. How will you manage Kojo and ensure he has the best treatment possible?
1. Below is a list of eight (8) possible actions you can take to manage Kojo's case.
2. Select the correct actions from the list on your left and place it in the slots on your right.
3. How many of these options are right? That's up to you.

text: Diagnosis and case management, go hand in hand. Always make sure you know the right guideline actions to take after correctly diagnosing any health issue.

dialogues.text: Aunty Nurse, so what next?
Don't worry. I will refer you to a higher health facility. They will take good care of you.

text: Adwoa. Provide Kojo with a referral note for the next level facility staff.

dialogues.text: Whew, I'm glad I spotted Kojo's treatment failure.
Someday soon, all my hardwork will pay off. I know it.

text: Adwoa. Guess what? You've been selected to do midwifery training.

dialogues.text: Wow, Really. My hard work is paying off sooner than I thought.
Midwifery training, here I come.

text: Pregnant woman arrives at OPD of Clinic

dialogues.text: Good morning Nurse.
Hello Madam. What brings you to the clinic today?
My little girl was not well, so I brought her, they realised she has malaria.
So she has been treated?
Yes, but I told the nurse, that I have a slight headache. She asked me to see you.
Slight headache? Your daughter has malaria. We need to do an RDT immediately.

text: Hey Adwoa, Let's wash our hands first with soap and water
To use an item from the Handwashing Toolkit, click on it.
Adwoa. Take an RDT Cassette and do a test.

dialogues.text: Madam. You have malaria. Is your red card here?
No.
I'll get you a temporary card.
What two questions would you ask her?

text:
You've confirmed malaria with a positive RDT test for a pregnant patient. Now you need to ask her questions to help manage her case. Ready?

1. Below is a list of 4 possible questions you can ask.
2. Pick the two (2) correct questions to ask.
3. Let's Go!

Asking the wrong questions, gets you the right answers for the wrong diagnosis. Malaria in Pregnancy guidelines protect the life of both mother and baby and as a midwife it is essential you know them intimately.

dialogues.text: Madam when did you have your last menstrual period.
18 weeks ago.
She has not started SP treatment yet. The right treatment is...

text:
Your pregnant patient is in her 2nd Trimester (18 weeks), confirmed positive for malaria. What is the right treatment for her.

1. Below is a list of possible actions you can take in treating your patient.
2. Select the right actions from the list of possible actions. Remember all the actions could be correct!
3. Let's Go!
Diagnosis and case management, go hand in hand. Always make sure you know the right guideline actions to take after correctly diagnosing any health issue.

dialogues.text: Okay, then I will give you ACTs (Artesunate Amodiaquine - AA).
A month later you will come for SP.
Yes Nurse.
Another successful, day. Another patient getting the treatment they need.
I love my job and the opportunity to touch people's lives positively!

text: YES! You are ready to progress to the next level. As a nurse you know what that means right? It's time for an EXAM.
There are 10 Questions. You need to score at least 80% (8/10) to proceed.
Pass this and you will have earned the right to the next Grade as a Nurse.
Oh No! You didn't get the pass mark required.
Let's give it another try and this time, let's get it right

pages.text:
Congrats, You have completed this chapter of Hello Nurse.
To be Continued
